description.text:
The triggers in both my Aldi ratchet clamps failed - possibly because I'd left them clamping something (lightly) for several months.
Probably not as strong as the original, but at least I can use the clamps.

Printer:

Robox

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: Made in Robox ABS.
I would have used PLA but the machine that I use for PLA is out of action - temporarily, I hope!
I used a brim.

Obviously clean off the brim and support material.
The holes are 4mm and 5mm diameter. I cleaned these to size using a hand reamer (for handles see: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:386855)

I scanned the broken parts in an Epson flat bed scanner. Married together the images in Picture Window Pro and used the resultant composite image as the starting point for 3D model design in Moment of Inspiration.

description.text: The most recent source files will always be in the quarter-turn-mount github repository.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: should print pretty easy
Use 8-10mm m4 nuts and screws to secure the quarter-turn mount to the mount arm. Use 15mm m4 nuts and screws to secure the mount to the handlebars.

There are at least a couple other similar quarter-turn mounts out there, but one author says that his broke, and the other only published stl files, and the parts didn't fit together. Plus, I don't like using zip-ties to secure things to my handlebars.
So, I designed my own and published all of the source files, so you can modify it to your heat's content.
I've been using prototypes of this mount for a hundred miles or so, and so far, so good.

This is the build plate for a PrintrBot Simple Metal. Simplify 3D uses stl files to give pictures of the build volume for reference. There wasn't one for the PrintrBot Simple Metal, so I decided to make one. This is not intended to be printed, but is merely for modelling purposes.

1) Download the stl file, remember the location.
2) Open up Simplify 3D
3) If you haven't added your PrintrBot Simple Metal, go to Help-> Configuration Assistant, and add your PrintrBot Simple Metal.
4) Go to Tools->Options
5) Click on the "Machine Tab"
6) In the window marked "Printer Models", hit "Add"
7) Navigate to your downloaded stl file.
8) Choose a color. I chose a charcoal grey (HTML: #3e3e3e)
9) Click "Okay"

This is a pedestrian reflector pendant for use in dark periods when walking in car-traffic areas.
We live in a suburb where everyone walks on the streets where car traffic is present. As a driver I have been scared many times when I noticed a person (who is usually one of my neighbours) at the last moment and pass a few tenths centimetres by.
Pedestrians think that drivers see them if they can see the car. And they are absolutely wrong!
So I have bought on eBay some reflective sticker tape and decided to make some reflector-pendants to give away to pedestrians if I see them in the dark times on the street and if they are dressed invisibly to drivers.

Printer:

Mamba3D

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

No

0.295mm

10%

Notes: Have made "MickeyMouse ears" to keep good adhesion to the print-bed on the corners. you can cut them off when printed. Or if you have the adhesion issue solved for yourself then there is an .stl without cut-off extensions.

author: juancamilo

description.text:
So when I bought a 3d printer, I thought I definitely need dual extruder's, ill use them all the time, its definitely a requirement.. In actuality, I've used it only a few times, all it is really, is dead weight. So in an attempt to reduce the weight on the gantry and thus reduce strain on everything, and even maybe increase speed and accuracy capabilities, I've made a blanking nema 17. its a simple fit, pictured it is in PLA, but I've just finished my rev1, which ill print out and update the files, as well as weights, as it stands now, the original assy weighed in at 287 grams, my print, and associated hardware weighed in at 24 grams, for a incredible saving of 263 grams! In ABS, we've shaved another 3 grams off the assy, bringing the total weight saving to 266 grams!!!! I tried making a 'lightweight' version, but it just looked messy, but ill keep on it!
Have decided to scrap the whole 'lightweight' version, its not worth it for 5-6 grams, i saw a max of 8 gram saving, but the structure is quite weak, atleast the uploaded version looks somewhat normal and is strong, so I am staying with it and will be printing it in ABS soon All you have to do post print is clean up the mount holes with a 1/8" drill bit, slip through your mounting screws and throw some nuts on the back! To be printed in ABS since the mount block gets hot enough to soften pla. PLA 20 grams
ABS 17 grams

This is an enclosure for a Harbor Freight hoist switch that you can mount to the wall. The one that comes with the hoist works fine, but if you have a permanent setup for a hoist then mounting the switch to the wall rather than using the supplied hand-held switch may be something you'd want. My first try was a 3-piece assembly (Clip.stl, Top.stl, Base.stl) and it almost worked but the time I took fiddling with it made the thing crack, crack, and crack now and then and by the time I was "done" it was not good. Plus, the switch hole was too small to work without filing a bunch out of it. The next attempt (Top 1.stl, Base 1.stl) reduced it to two parts which can be put together after all the tabs or soldering is done with lots of slack in the wire. Hole is properly sized for the switch to just slip into place. Screwing the two halves together clamps the wire in place at the same time, so no separate wire clamp is needed.
Also, making the long tabs which "nest" together helps a little to reduce the tendency of the print to warp and lift from the build plate.

description.text:
This is a remix of waltherion's "Awesome Dart Holder for Nerf Gun" creation (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:714721). It easily attaches to the tactical rail of your Nerf gun and holds 6 or 8 darts. The modifications from the original include:

Also, the spring force of the tactical rail latch is nearly twice on one from the other which can create a stiff ratcheting effect. author: vfalendysh

description.text:
Based on Deluxe TARDIS kit by countspatula. 
I recommend printing this anywhere between 150% size and 240% size. 190% hits you right at 12".  I left the parts the same size so that it was still printable on 6" printers without having to resize it.
I decided to make a big one of these, but I wanted storage, so I added three drawers, and added cutouts to the bottom of some of the parts to allow for a USB cable to be run in to power any lights you might add.
Remember, the notch on the drawer goes toward the FRONT. When gluing the panels onto the drawers, just yous a flat surface to align the bottom, and center it by eye.
The drawer insert is a tight fit, but at my print of 190%, it fit just tightly enough that it doesn't move.

Printer Brand:

Type A Machines

Printer:

2014 Series 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20%

Notes: With low layer height, make sure you are using plenty of top and bottom layers. I ran this with 5 on bottom and 7 on top. This made SURE that I had no gaps or sags due to infill. Print the drawers at 0.3, and use a concentric top surface pattern for all the blue parts if you can. Both Slic3r and Simplify3d have this option. It makes the pattern look more wood-like. The windows were a bit of a tight fit, use Simplify3d's horizontal size compensation, or reduce your flow rate if that isn't an option. I found justPLA's Navy Blue to be a good choice for blue. Finding a darkish, vivid, opaque blue in PLA hasn't bean easy.

Paint the inside areas around the windows and the bottom of the lid with an opaque paint. I find that liquid electrical tape actually bonds VERY well to PLA and is very opaque with just one coat.
When gluing the panels to the drawers, be certain the cutout is toward the front of the drawer. That's the side the panel glues to. To align the drawer panel with the drawer, just make sure the bottom of both are aligned, and use your eye to center the panel against the front of the drawer.
The drawer insert can bit a tight fit. If need be, reduce it's size by 1% (as well as the drawers themselves).

Based on countspatula's Deluxe TARDIS kit, I used Sketchup and Netfabb Basic to do most of the work and make sure things were watertight.
Sliced using Simplify3D and printed on a 2014 Type A Machines Series 1 at 0.1 for visible areas, and 0.3 everywhere else.

comments.text: How hard are the draws to open?  It doesn't look like there is any sort of knob or handle to help pull them open.

comments.text: The center post on that panel is a little bit extended, and tapered inwardly. The drawers slide very easily, and can pull the drawers. If you print a small one (100% or under), then you'll probably need to use your nail to pull. I just increased the size of that center ridge and uploaded it. The current version should be a little easier for small prints.

description.text:
This is a replacement for the stock landing gear of the Tarot 250 racer. I is designed to be unbreakable using flexible filament, giving enough rigidity to absorb impact and protect electronics. It is about 2cm shorter than the original giving the Tarot a sleeker look. Because of the flexible filament, the holes for the tubes are tight and stretch, this means that it won't work on any rigid filament unless you modify the file which is in .prt or .igs . It requires replacement landing skid tubes form HobbyKing or other distributor for standard 450 helis. UPDATE
I have been using this landing gear for a while and it has been great. I have had several accidents or descended way too fast and hard after flips (the original landing gear would have broken) and it just bounces and absorbs all the impact. It worked better than expected.

remixed_from.author: SuperSolid_3D
remixed_from.title: Lulzbot TAZ bearing / bushing holders with tightening clamps

title: Taz 5 single and double bushing holders with tightening clamps

description.text:
The IGUS bushings on my Taz 5 printer have quite a bit of slop, resulting in banding and errors in prints. I'm too cheap to buy the ball bearing + hardened rod upgrade - so I opted to print parts and MacGyver the bearings. I am using the original IGUS bushings, but slotted them lengthwise with a hacksaw and stuffed the PVC insulation from 22awg wire into the cut in the bearing. The result is that the bushing can be compressed in the carrier. Before securing the carrier to the rest of the stage on the machine, tighten the screws on the bushing clamp while it is on the rod. Make sure it still moves freely (but now without slop) when you reattach the carrier to the machine. As the bushings wear, the screws can be tightened to keep slop to a minimum. This is a remix from SuperSolid_3D's modification - all I did was add more screws and make a surround for the M3 nut so it doesn't spin. I'd recommend nyloc nuts to help keep the bushing clamp from loosening from vibration/heat cycling: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000NBKLOQ? Using 123d design and Tinkercad, my models were not manifold. I used the MS Netfabb online app to repair them. https://netfabb.azurewebsites.net/ Parts and tools you'll need to complete this thing: For each single bushing holder:
3x M3 screw 20mm long
3x M3 nyloc nuts For each double bushing carrier:
6x M3 screw 20mm long
6x M3 nyloc nuts 1 foot or so of 22AWG wire Wire stripper Hacksaw A vise to hold bushings while slotting them.
  • If you don't want to cut a slot in your original IGUS bushings, you can always print up IGUS bearings and use those instead of the originals: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1019671

description.text: If you are a new drone flyer and you have a X8C, you are eventually gonna need one (or more) of these.  This is modeled on the original.  There is a slight weight penalty for the remake.  The original prop guard weighs 6 grams.  This one at 2 shells and 10% infill weighed 10 grams with PLA.  Still, this prop guard is much more rigid than the original.  Fit has been verified on two different X8C drones, so it is a drop in replacement.

remixed_from.author: dolpin
remixed_from.title: Advanced Delta Printer Calibration (tower position + individual diagonal rod)

title: Delta printer calibration object - rod lengths only (faster print time)

description.text:
This is a slight mod of dolpin's excellent rostock calibration object.
I had some problems with rod lengths so I wanted a faster way of re-checking them after each change. This object is simply the 'pegs' for measuring from dolpin's file, without the base. It means you can print it in 10 minutes instead of 40 mins :)
The file will also automatically centre as I left a tiny amount of the 'base' there, but your slicer should ignore it as it's too thin.
Measure the blocks on each axis after printing - they should be 60mm apart.

description.text:
NOTE: This thing is under development. See the comments concerning grtbaldini's make This is a customized version of Smooth X-axis for Prusa i3 with Leadscrews for 10mm smooth rod and LM10UU linear bearings.
  • The distance between Z-axis's smooth rod and leadscrew is 30mm (grtbaldini's setup) or 19mm (spacecase151's setup)
  • Belt tensioner parts are the same (could make it 3mm wider for this)
  • Use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1270385 to connect Rework -type extruder to X-carriage

description.text:
This is a mechanism designed to lock and unlock a door by mechanically turning the lock cylinder using a servo motor controlled by an Arduino. By using a wireless Arduino shield the door can be locked and unlocked remotely from a mobile phone app. In this prototype I’ve used the SmartThings Arduino shield for the network connectivity (it connects to a SmartThings hub using a Zigbee network). The mechanics is based on the Worm Gear Reducer, published by Mattheus (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:41161).
This is a first prototype. It uses a simple (and cheap) HS-311 servo motor, converted into a continuous rotation servo. The mechanics is simple and reliable and it provides enough torque to turn the lock, by using the reducer. The mechanism is rather slow (a full turn of the key takes more than a minute). This design trades torque for speed. This way it is able to turn the lock using a small and relatively weak servo motor which doesn’t require much current and it can be driven directly by the Arduino. The prototype is powered by a portable USB charger.
The model was designed using Sketchup. Here is a link to the Sketchup files on 3D Warehouse, so the design can be modified (e.g. to fit other types of locks). https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model.html?id=u49c8e7b9-ba90-4d48-9280-3fb5b7a23cf7

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%, 40%

The assembled mechanism Assembly and Setup I used ABS for all the printed parts. The worm gear is printed with 40% fill. All the other parts are printed with 20% fill. The layer thickness is 0.2mm for all the parts. Bill of Materials:
Arduino Board (I used Arduino Mega, but any will do)
SmartThings Arduino Shield (or any other wireless connectivity shield)
HS-311 Servo motor
A portable USB charger
Pushbuttons X2 (for local lock/unlock without using the mobile app)
M3X50 screw
M3X30 screws X3
M3X20 screws X4
M3X10 screws X2
M3X5 screws X4
M3 nuts X6
Double sided adhesive tape
Some wire for connections (22 AWG)
The printed servo adapter must fit tightly on the servo motor shaft. To get the exact diameter you may need to use a 5.5mm drill. Once you get the right diameter you should tighten the adapter to the servo shaft using two m3X5 screws.
The servo motor should be modified to a continuous rotation servo (here’s how: https://www.flickr.com/photos/randomskk/2569969633).
In the Arduino sketch there are parameters to control the rotation time, speed and angle. These parameters should be adjusted to your specific lock cylinder.

author: glennkreisel

title: Linear Bearing holder IGUS compatible, updated!

description.text:
I've updated this to make it compatible with my IGUS drylin bearings.
I've added three more models with different hole sizes to fit, depending on how your printers dimensional accuracy holds up. I found the 15.25mm was a good fit on the IGUS bearing, If it's too tight the bearing will be crushed and pinch instead of sliding freely.
If in doubt as to which size pick one and just print 4mm or so and try it.
Obviously it shouldn't be too tight or loose, so test it on a 8mm rod to make sure. This is a linear bearing holder that was designed to be a direct replacement for the aluminium holder that is used in many 3d printers. I wanted to be able to use 3d printed LM8UU size linear bearings but didn't want to dismantle the aluminium ones. to assemble them.
The bearings should be a tight(ish) push fit. Just file to fit if needed. Plus this should be much lighter than the metal ones so less mass to move around. After some testing, using the printed toothed linear bearings below, the printer is so much quieter. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18219 Please comment if you have any suggestions. I've checked the dimensions are the same as my original aluminium ones.

comments.text: These are for LM8UU size bearings, so 8mm

author: expert2k

description.text:
Parametric Lego Planetary Gear System. Most important parameter (to adjust the big annular gear):
ToothGapRadial = 0.5; This parameter might need to be adjusted depending on the quality of the 3D printer used. For an accurate printer, the default value should be fine. I did use a value of 1.0 to produce a usable annular gear. Following configurations of epicyclic gearings are supported:
  • 8 teeth sun gear and 3x16 teeth planet gears (use carrier 2)
  • 16 teeth sun gear and 3x12 teeth planet gears (use carrier 3)
  • 24 teeth sun gear and 3x8 teeth planet gears (use carrier 1)
    • Instead of using a specific carrier type (1,2,3), one can also use the multi carrier type for any configuration. The gears themselves have also been modeled in openscad. However these do not need to the printed in case one owns the original Lego gears.
  • 8 teeth gear (PartNr 3647)
  • 12 teeth gear (PartNr 32270)
  • 16 teeth gear (PartNr 4019)
  • 24 teeth gear (PartNr 3648a)

comments.text: I tried printing this on a Lulzbot Mini (0.5mm nozzle) with Colorfabb nGen. It looked beautiful, but the axle and peg holes were too small to use with actual Lego parts. What printer, what size nozzle and what material was the example printed with? I'm trying to decide whether this is a scaling or tolerance issue.
comments.author: neamerjell

comments.text: The STL files are neutral files; so no corrections are applied. If you look into the OpenSCAD file, you will see I defined a variable called "PRINTABLE" which is set to 0. (no corrections active then)
comments.author: neamerjell

comments.text: Thanks for the info. Now I know it is not due to a calibration issue or nozzle diameter causing resolution issues.

description.text: This is derived from my other enclosure where I decided to eliminate all the enclosure parts so I could install the new 10" X-Axis upgrade without making this giant table box enclosure. So I went with an open air design that can still hold a full size power supply, LCD control panel. SD card extender, cooling fan, spool holder, USB panel plate and there is still room for a Raspberry Pi. The whole box is as short as it can be because of the LCD and power supply then the Printrbot is recessed into it as low as possible while still allowing the bed to clear the sides. Even with the printrbot lowered there is still 2" of open air under the whole unit to allow for the cooling fan to keep the electronics nice and cool. IT also stabilizes the whole printer. If you don't have access to a laser cutter let me know and we can work something out. Be sure to check out my other enclosure if you don't plan on getting the extended bed. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:828774

title: Wireless ham radio frequency counter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Frequency counter enclosure.
It is designed for use wireless with internal 9v battery and any antenna. I drilled a 6.5mm hole on the top case for fitting a SMA type connector (i designed without this hole just for your choice).
I tested several antennas from my RC and Ham radio stuff (VHF-UHF types) and get the best results with the larger one, also tested the counter on HF, VHF and UHF bands with the same antenna getting great and precise results. You can also attach a simple wire if you dont have any antenna.
If you want a wired varinat of this thing check this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1160233 I have my 11m ham radio perfect PLL aligned using these types of counters and a simple multimeter. BOM:
-Use 4pcs M3x10mm and 4pcs M3x20mm bolts for the box. If you want to fix also the optional 35º angle holder you need to replace two of 20mm bolts by 25mm ones.
-Frecuency counter board: It is a cheap one (about 11€ at today date), works from 0,1MHz to 2.4GHz and has 8 digits.
-Switch type: It is a round type and the mounthing hole is 20mm diameter (mine has also a 12v LED inside).
-Battery: I use a 9v type one with connector.

This designs has a lot of effort and testings, so please if you like it and found usefull consider to make a donation, any amount will be really apreciate and you will contributing with improved and future designs. You can donate here: http://villamanydonate.blogspot.com Thank you!

This is my version of Skimmy's magnetic hotend changer, i liked his one and one of my hotends stil has that one - thanks skimmy :) but i wanted a few additions
this one should be mostly compatible with the original, i only added some stuff to it i made this for my Sparkcube XL for an E3D-V6 Hotend, its used with the original Carriage for the Spark, but i could guess that i loss a bit of building height with it - which doesnt matter for me if so but as i changed alot on my spark i cant say how much of the height is reduced because of these holder. All the Hotend-holder-parts including the Fanducts i printed with ABS ofc. with 2 of the E3D-V6 in exchange on my sparkcube its now used for around 200hrs of printing ABS (up to 260°C), and above 25hrs including the fanducts printing PLA (up to 210°C). i dont have tried other Hotends than the E3D with it yet...
The fanducts are used with PLA only, and even as i thought it would... no issues with melting yet even without using the 40mm-fans for a while, i guess the E3D-fan helps a bit from inside aswell. the parts itself: first there is the mounting plate which is screwed to the carriage (green in the CAD-pics). In comparsion to skimmy's only the big hole is a lil bit bigger to have some more space for screws and cables, but it should work also with the original one the hotend holder itself (yellow) i changed a bit more
the mounting parts (magnets and such) are completely like in skimmy ones - so it should work well together, but i added 3 holes including space for M3 Nuts on the center. With these and some screws and washers i fix the hotend itself in its place like it was made in my Mendel90, so i dont need such an exact fitting print and also not these additional printed part to fix the E3D-V6.
then - also in the center - i added 2 round gaps - which i use for the cables, one for the hotend itself, and the other one for optionals like the pla fanduct cables.
and last but not least i added 8 holes including Nuts on the sides to be able to add other parts to the hotend. Like this i have 2 M4 on each side i can use. and then there are the light blue fanduct parts - 2 of them are used by me for pla-prints.
they are made for 40mm-fans and have enough room for the usual 30mm E3D-Hotend-Fanduct
The fanducts are screwed on the magnet holder with 4 M4x16 countersunk screws (each fanduct has 2),
and it has 4 2.5mm-holes for 3mm-screws to add the fans.
when removing the hotend with the magnets the fanducts are removed aswell. by the way: the black duct tape on the magnets in the photos are not needed, i only had them as my magnets had kind of a tooo strong force that i had problems to unmount the holder ;)

description.text:
Scale model shipping containers to play around with, add to your ship or train models or brainstorm your container house (which is what I'm doing). The default size is 1/144 but you can obviously scale them as necessary. Double for 1/72
Tripple for 1/48
x4.5 for 1/32

I printed these with a .1 honeycomb fill. Nothing fancy. BUT USE BED HEAT. I got some curling on the edges that would certainly have been solved with a constant bed heat throughout the build. (I was also experimenting with settings.)

description.text: This is a mostly functional replacement keyfob for a Lotus Elise or Exige. To use it, you have to get a copy of your key made on a key that is all metal without the plastic handle, then, with a hacksaw, cut the key to fit into the slot in the new keyfob. Transfer the electronics from the original keyfob to the new casing. Note: The casing is not watertight, nor does it snap together, so you need to either glue it together (then, changing the battery becomes a problem, but you can pry it apart with pliers and destroy it and then just print out another one) or tape it together. I have had the thing fall apart in my pocket one time, and it esp. needs something to hold it together when twisting it (e.g. as when you turn the ignition on.) This thing isn't even close to perfect, but, it's alright. Feel free to make improvements. The canonical OpenSCAD source is here: https://github.com/smcameron/buzzbomb-keyfob License is GPL v2 or later. Feel free to send me patches.
Print it out, transfer electronics from old keyfob, Make a copy of your key on an all-metal key.  Hacksaw new key to fit into new casing.  Tape or glue casing together.

Automatic fish feeder for aquarium. I made this feeder in to our nano reef aquarium.
I have a Siemens Logo! which drivers the motor in the feeder.
The holes are made for small pellets (1.5mm x 1.5mm) which many times got
stuck in our Rondomatic feeder due the moisture.
Now all of the pellets have gone in to the tank without any problems.
The glass thickness in the tank is 6mm. The motor used is a DealExtreme SKU: 214121
There is also a fitting for a ball bearing in the lid, but I did not use any bearings.
I used a 3mm drill to clear the holes for the bolts.
There is a need for heating when assembling the motor Axel and the nuts.
That is because I wanted to make a very tight fit.

Printer:

Prenta Duo XL

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20 %

Notes: Printed in PLA at 210°.

comments.text: Hi! How do you control the motor and ensure the wheel stops when it is supposed to?  Do you have an IR sensor?  Are you able to do it with timing?
comments.author: raudette

comments.text:
Hi,
Siemens Logo! does the controlling, and I have used a Logo!'s internal timer function.
Used time will depend of the motor and the print itself, so that is what you should find out when you have a complete setting assembled.
Or you can use some other sensor to make a desired spin as you prefer.

author: rayjmo

description.text:
These are MakeBeam 10cm prototype .STL files that have been run through "Magics 14 64bit" to remove all kinds of errors and make play nice with the majority of 3D printers throughout the world... (courtesy of Materialise)
I've included a 254mm (10") for yucks (if you print on a Dimension - wrap it with support material otherwise it will bend on you ...) Note: as a curiosity I made a horizontal an a vertical lay/orientation - and as you would guess the horizontal is a lot stronger. If I had unlimited funds, it would be interesting to do real testing to see at which orientation (90, 60, 45, 15, 0 with rotation components also - permutations get astronomical), would be best to build for overall beam performance verses maximizing in a single plane of force (vertical lay/orientation with no side forces would win hands down, compression load only)
download and print - most important have fun !

comments.text: Really cool!  Thanks!  I was trying to do something similar, but was at a loss as to how to easily clean it up without having to redraw the model.  Note that the bottom is below the build surface in the posted STL file- I used skeinforge on it directly and crashed my build platform. :-)

remixed_from.title: Flexing battery holders with integrated spring

description.text:
This is a remix of the Battery Holder by enif. As I did not find a suitable case for my 12V MN21 I resized the AAA one.
It can be printed on ABS (maybe better for elasticity) or PLA . I used PLA .
The first attempt the print resulted a bit small so I modified the STL file .
In case you print with PLA and your case results too small, simply let the top part of it (spring)
into acetone (use proper protection !!) for 1 min, it will add flexibility to it ! In case the battery remains loosen then increase the diameter of electrical wire used to connect it on both side.
Holds a full American sized 12oz can. Soda or beer.

author: snagman667

title: LIPO battery mount with alarm bag

description.text:
This is a LIPO battery mount for my robot car, "Mr. Stitson". http://dlacko.blogspot.com/2016/01/mr-stitson-kid-friendly-arduino-lego.html I designed it such a way that (1) the battery can be replaced without removing the cover of the robot (2) it also has a bag for the LIPO alarm (3) the alarm is easy to connect to the battery. To fulfill these requirements the mount is made from two parts attached to each other by two 3M screws, but only one of these parts is attached directly to the chassis of the robot. To remove the battery, first disconnect the XT60 connector and the alarm, then unscrew the two screws (this can be done without removing the cover). This enables to remove the outer part of the mount, revealing the battery. Some comments:

  • Disconnecting the XT60 connector is much easier than it seems. You can just pull the cable of the battery outwards a bit to let the connector get out of its mount (it should not be very tight). When it is not under the cover any more, it is easy to disconnect.

  • Glue the M3 nuts into their place

  • It is for batteries with XT60 connector, but I believe it is easy to adapt to other kinds

description.text:
Use to keep the Larger springs available for the wanhao i3 centered and in place without movement.
Use a M3 nylock to secure it to the underside of your heated bed, then the spring then another holder than through the bottom bed plate and finally securing with the bed knobs using another M3 nylock. This will remove most wiggle in the bed causing issues with printing.
PRINT IN ABS to prevent warping as the heated bed will soften PLA.
Will need 8 of these if using abs, or if using PLA use 4, on on the bottom of each corder above the bottom plate.

author: snagman667

title: Yet another useless box with Arduino and 5g servo

description.text:
Why I designed yet another useless box? Because I can! Because I did not find on Thingiverse any design that I was fully satisfied. Some of them use motors, while I had only servos. Others supposed to use direct motor connection, while I wanted to program several scenarios with Arduino. Finally some of the designs I just did not like. Moreover I wanted to practice in creating complex mechanisms with moving parts as well as Arduino programming. So my design supposed to:
  • Be tiny if possible
  • No screws on visible panels
  • Use 5g servo
  • Use Arduino Nano
  • Powered by 9V battery block
  • Hidden power switch
    • There are 2 playing modes. One is normal - player clicks the switch and box switches it back. When player bothers the box too much (at least 4 clicks with less than 2 seconds between them) the box starts to tease the player. See the https://youtu.be/XJRB2Mc1x-I how does it look like Unfortunately I failed with the first attempt. It was too complex (or even impossible) to assembly. This is the second design, but still it has number of annoyance in assembly. There are too much screws that are hard to access. So I am attaching solidworks file so you are welcome to remix and fix the issues. Note: use alkaline batteries. Arduino often hangs and reboot on cheap batteries (you may notise hangs on the video) UPDATE: in order to fix Arduino hang issue when working on battery, I added a MC34063-based step down coverter. I used self-made one, but you can order factory produced board on ebay/aliexpress. In my case it improved things a little bit. Voltage still drops down to 4V when servo is switches the lever, but at lease this does not reboot arduino. Of course the converter output should be conected to +5V pin, not to VIN Basically I think using 9V block is not the best idea for driving the servo. It is better to use LiPo 7.4V 300mAh battery

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Graber i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm nozzle, 0.2mm layer

Infill:

20

The assembly may be a little sophisticated. Here is the algorithm.
  • Print everything. Drill screw holes with 1.5mm drill.
  • Mount ‘cap mount’ part with a piece of 1.5mm rod.
  • Glue Cap to Cap mount
  • Add a small spring, one end mount at the special hook on the cap’s bottom. As for other – find a place to secure it with a screw on a wall. I used a small screw at the servo pylon.
  • Mount Arm on the servo. You may need to cut native servo arm a little bit so that it fits to the printed one.
  • Cut the servo wire, leaving about 10cm. Do not solder it for now
  • Pass wire through the hole in servo mount, then mount the servo. You may need to cut another wire hole in the servo shell so that wire goes right way. Do not screw servo right now, since you may need to remove it few times to adjust the arm
  • Now you may solder servo wires to Arduino – black (brown) wire to the GND pin, red to 5V pin, yellow to D2
  • Solder wires to the switch. Solder other ends to Arduino's GND and D4 pins.
  • Solder power wires from the battery connector (I used one from other battery). Minus wire goes directly to Arduino’s GND pin, Plus wire goes through power switch, then to VIN pin.
  • Upload firmware and try it working. At this point you may consider adjusting servo arm position, or even correct moving bounds in the firmware (max_pos and min_pos constants)
  • Now you may secure servo parts (arm and servo itself) with screws
  • Mount switch on the top plate
  • Mount the top plate on the main box and secure with 4 tiny screws (I used 5x2 screws)
  • Mount Arduino. I used just 2 screws – one underneath power switch, other diagonal for the first one
  • Mount power switch (mine has screwless mount)
  • Glue 4 battery hooks to the bottom plate
  • Place battery between hooks, connect it to the power connector
  • Now you may screw the bottom panel to the main box shell
  • Mount false panel (so people do not see electronic guts). This part is not precisely designed, so you may need to cut it a little bit where needed. Screw the panel with 3 screws.

title: Halter für Kopfhörer, verstellbar mit WOT Logo / Holder for earphones, adjustable

description.text:
Es gibt viele Halter für Kopfhörer. Mal in S-Form, mal zum direkten Anschrauben. Aber es hat keinen gegeben, wo ich beliebig verstellen kann und so einstellen wie ich es gern hätte. (zumindest hab ich den nicht gefunden). Deshalb hab ich mir den gezeichnet. Mein Monitor hat auf der Rückseite eine gerade Fläche, so dass das befestigen mit doppelseitigem Klebeband perfekt ist. Natürlich lässt sich der Halter auch anschrauben.
Zum fixieren einfach eine 3,5 x (mind.) 15 mm Holzschraube eindrehen.

There are lots of holder for headphones. Time in S-shape, sometimes for direct screwing. But there has been no where I can adjust as desired and adjust the way I would have liked. (at least I have the not found). Therefore, I've drawn the. My monitor has on the back a flat surface, so that the attach with double sided tape is perfect. Of course, the holder can also screw.
For easy fix a 3.5 x (min.) 15 mm wood screw screw.

title: KFz-Halter mit Wireless-Charger Samsung S3, S6, IPhone5

description.text:
Da ich es leid bin meiner Tochter ständig Ladekabel zu löten bzw. neu zu kaufen oder die Buchse im Handy wieder an zu löten wollte ich ihr IPhone 5 auf Wireless-Charging umbauen und auch eine Halterung für ihr Auto drucken. Bei der Gelegenheit hab ich auch eine Halterung für mein Samsung S6 entworfen.
Benötigt wird:
1x Anker PowerPort Qi
1x LKL3 MICRO USB Dauerstrom Adapter 12V zu 2A / 5V (oder ein USB Steckernetzteil)
4x Schraube M4x12 mit Mutter
Zusätzlich für's IPhone:
1x iProtect Qi-kompatible induktive Schutzhülle Apple iPhone 5 5s
Zusätzlich für's Samsung S3:
1x kwmobile Qi Receiver für Samsung Galaxy S3, (kommt unter den Deckel auf den Akku)

Doesn't Matter

Yes

0,2 mm

20%

Angel: 80,
Spacing: 1 mm,
Margin: 0,5,
Density: 0,2,
Extra Support,
Leaky Connections

Konstruiert ist das Ganze mit Creo. Habe zu lernzwecken versucht den Halter zu parametrieren, Damit ich nur die Abmessungen des Handys und die Lage der Induktionsspule eingeben muß und einen passenden Halter exportieren kann.
Mein Samsung S6 steckt in einer "Bestwe X-Line TPU Skin Case Samsung Galaxy S6 Silikon Hülle" entsprechend sind die Abmessungen etwas größer. Abmessungen: 146mm x 75mm x 9,5mm, Spule mittig, für's Iphone5 130mm x 61.5mm x10mm, Spule mittig.
Weil's so einfach war noch 3 Halter : Samsung-S6 ohne Hülle und Samsung S3 mit und ohne Hülle.
Heute hab ich noch Samsung S6 mit Hülle im Querformat hinzugefügt!

description.text:
A friend who is a doctor travels a lot carrying ultrasound equipment. The transducers are vulnerable, expensive, and not packaged by the manufacturer for portability; so he wanted protective covers for the most vulnerable part, the probe end. This design covers the three probes in his kit, and is extensible for additional probes as they are acquired. The three probes included here are:
•Sonoscape L741
•Sonoscape C344
•Sonoscape 2P1

After printing the two halves, I lined the interiors with self-adhesive felt, purchased at craft stores in 8.5x11 sheets.
For hinge pins, I straightened out ordinary paper clips with a diameter of 1 mm. Push the pin through all 4 hinge barrels, then bend it so it doesn't slide out. I bent mine in the middle, into a loop, onto which a small retaining strap can be linked.
Made to go on most any of the great 3D Catan Terrain Pieces, while sitting on top of the Number Token.  Prints great with a small support in the hollow base.

Printer:

XYZprinting da Vinci Jr.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.03

Infill:

Low (10%)

Notes: Be careful removing the support under the base. :)

K, Bought a WHOLE bunch of cheap .5 VDC, 5 AMP solar cells from EBay.  They work beautifully, BUT, they are brittle.  So, out comes 3-D printer and print the holder for these.  I recommend a very small dab of hot glue so the solar cell can move just a bit.  Use bendable braided wire (that can handle the amperage.  I went with about 4.5 amps) as the solar cells DO put out 5 amps at .5 vdc, but that  is in perfect conditions.
I was going to print connection(s) on the ends/sides (Little dovetails or something like that), feel free to modify.  Lemme know how you guys/gals make out.
Cheers!

I had an extra couple of 40mm box fans (same ones used to cool the extruder on the Replicator) on my desk and on a whim hooked it up to a power supply. Cool little fan, but it kept wanting to precess and wouldn't stay upright. So I whipped this up. I really tried to make it look like a jet engine. Haven't printed it out yet.
I would suggest printing with the pointy end facing up to reduce support. The STL files should have them oriented that way already. UPDATE: I just realized that the rear section had some mirroring issues. Fixed that with v3
Use M3 x 20 socket head cap screws to hold it together. Tap the rear half with M3 x .5. There is a little slot for the power wire.

comments.text:
This is the coolest fan cover I have ever seen! :) is there any way you could increase the total depth of where the fan goes in by 2mm? I seem to have a 2mm gap when putting together and the fans I have are pretty standard 10.5mm thick. If you could also loosen the tolerances around the fan hole itself to maybe .5mm, it may allow for easier fit when printing ABS without tweaking or resizing.
The only thing I found odd was that because of the orientation of your fan cable hole, the fan goes in backwards opposed to the way that air is sucked in an out of a normal jet engine housing. if that hole/exit passage was mirrored, the fan could then be placed so air comes in through the other end.
awesome job! looking forward to see if you have time to make any changes.
Cheers

title: Freebord Binding Fix
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
this is a fix for the Freebord S2 bindings which covers the gap between the hooks and the deck. There are 4 sizes, 3.0,4.0,5.0, and 6.0. The 6.0 is for bindings set with the screw in the top hole (highest setting). The 3.0 is for the binding set with the screw at the 3rd hole from the bottom. When installed properly on square base plates there should be less than 1mm of space left anywhere on hook. There is a block that needs to be removed and is in the print only as a support. Once removed slide the bindingfix of the correct size onto the baseplate first then slide the hook ontop, insert 2 screws and tighten. some light sanding might be necessary if the fit is not as desired. These originals were printed with PLA, so they my shrink slightly with other materials. You may have to adjust them accordingly.
If you like would like a version that fits any hole get the (Freebord binding fixer multi)
I would love it if you could leave feedback and makes thank you! enjoy!

left_message = `16
This project is a engineers prospective of what a 3d printer can and can not do. It shows where the printer will fail and where it is strong .

Objectives The student will be expected to learn what a 3D printer is capable of. The student will see what the 3D printer will fail at. They will also see what the printers strong points are. Audiences The age for this project would be 12 and up.
The skill required is almost none, but the student must be able to understand what they are learning. Preparation The student needs to know almost nothing it just depends on how easily they can understand what they are learning. The only thing you will need to start this project is a 3D printer and plastic for the printer. You may want to put a camera on the 3D printer so that if you dont have a one hour class. You can show the class a time laps of it printing the next day. Steps
  • Download the Thing File.
  • Put the Thing File into your printer.
  • Watch it print fail and accomplish its goal for your class.
  • Show the class what has happened to the print.
  • It will utterly fail on the left side.
  • It will be droopy in the front under the shaft. and under the curve on the right.
    • Results The student will be expected to tell the teacher where it failed and where it is strong.
    The student could also make a model, 3D print it and the teacher could grade the 3D printed object. The object should look clean and fine.

This spacer was designed for an ABEC 11 / Clone 90mm wheel and diyelectricskateboard.com 36T drive pulley / washer. From the looks of it, this should also work with the enertionboards.com pulley as well, no guarantees. The spacer distributes the pressure over the center of the hub and keeps everything straight. It should keep the hub from cracking due to over tightening the pulley. Slicing settings:
  • 0.2mm height
  • 4 solid layers top and bottom
  • 8 perimeters
  • 35% infill
    • After printing I drilled out the holes with a 1/4in bit. Update 02/21/2016 - Will also work with 83mm wheels. I think I should add that I drill out the hub with a 1/4in bit as well.

title: Clamp-on desk USB cable holder (improved V2)

description.text:
USB cable holder that will snugly clamp on the edge of a 19mm (3/4") thick desk without the need of fasteners. This is version 2.
Improvements:
-Increased space between slots and made retaining fingers longer. Will reduce the tendency of USB cables falling out of the holder
-Reduced thickness of the bottom part of the clamp. Will reduce filament use and printing time (still takes more filament and time than first version because it is longer) Make sure that the object is properly oriented so it is standing with the retaining fingers pointed up for better printing results. Only has 45 degree overhang.
Edit note: Fixed the scaling issue. It is now to 1:1 scale.
